findings.title: RSV - Redundant State Variable
findings.description: The contract uses a private state variable called `inserted` that determines if a user has participated in the contribution, but it is redundant because the state variable `allocationAmount` already stores the total allocation of every user.

findings.title: CR - Code Repetition
findings.description: The contract contains repetitive code segments which can lead to issues like gas efficiency, complexity, readability, security, and maintainability of the source code.

findings.title: MEM - Misleading Error Messages
findings.description: The contract uses misleading error messages which do not accurately reflect the problem, making it difficult to identify and fix the issue.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract is using variables that initialize them only in the constructor and are not defined as `immutable`. This can be improved by declaring a variable as immutable to enable Solidity compiler optimizations, reducing storage and computation required by the contract and making it more gas-efficient.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure the value cannot be changed after it has been set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
